trait.name: Antimagic Susceptibility
entries: The skeleton is {@condition incapacitated} while in the area of an {@spell antimagic field}. If targeted by {@spell dispel magic}, the skeleton must succeed on a Constitution saving throw against the caster's spell save DC or fall {@condition unconscious} for 1 minute.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the skeleton remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a normal pile of bones.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The skeleton makes two melee attacks.

action.name: Sharp fingers
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) slashing damage.

Animated objects are crafted with potent magic to follow the commands of their creators. When not commanded, they follow the last order they received to the best of their ability, and can act independently to fulfill simple instructions. Some animated objects (including many of those created in the Feywild) might converse fluently or adopt a persona, but most are simple automatons.

entries.name: Constructed Nature
entries: An animated object doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep. The magic that animates an object is dispelled when the construct drops to 0 hit points. An animated object reduced to 0 hit points becomes inanimate and is too damaged to be of much use or value to anyone.

entries.name: Animated Armor
entries: This empty steel shell clamors as it moves, heavy plates banging and grinding against one another like the vengeful spirit of a fallen knight. Ponderous but persistent, this magical guardian is almost always a suit of plate armor.

To add to its menace, animated armor is frequently enchanted with scripted speech, so the armor can utter warnings, demand passwords, or deliver riddles. Rare suits of animated armor are able to carry on an actual conversation.
